name: MedicationKnowledge
description: Information about a medication that is used to support knowledge.

element.short: Definition of Medication Knowledge
element.definition: Information about a medication that is used to support knowledge.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $id in f:contained/*/f:id/@value return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Code that identifies this medication
element.definition: A code that specifies this medication, or a textual description if no code is available. Usage note: This could be a standard medication code such as a code from RxNorm, SNOMED CT, IDMP etc. It could also be a national or local formulary code, optionally with translations to other code systems.
element.comment: Depending on the context of use, the code that was actually selected by the user (prescriber, dispenser, etc.) will have the coding.userSelected set to true.  As described in the coding datatype: "A coding may be marked as a "userSelected" if a user selected the particular coded value in a user interface (e.g. the user selects an item in a pick-list). If a user selected coding exists, it is the preferred choice for performing translations etc. Other codes can only be literal translations to alternative code systems, or codes at a lower level of granularity (e.g. a generic code for a vendor-specific primary one).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded concept that defines the type of a medication.

mapping.map: RXO-1.1-Requested Give Code.code / RXE-2.1-Give Code.code / RXD-2.1-Dispense/Give Code.code / RXG-4.1-Give Code.code /RXA-5.1-Administered Code.code / RXC-2.1 Component Code

element.short: active | inactive | entered-in-error
element.definition: A code to indicate if the medication is in active use.  The status refers to the validity about the information of the medication and not to its medicinal properties.
element.comment: This status is intended to identify if the medication in a local system is in active use within a drug database or inventory.  For example, a pharmacy system may create a new drug file record for a compounded product "ABC Hospital Special Cream" with an active status.  At some point in the future, it may be determined that the drug record was created with an error and the status is changed to "entered in error".   This status is not intended to specify if a medication is part of a particular formulary.  It is possible that the drug record may be referenced by multiple formularies or catalogues and each of those entries would have a separate status.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element changes the interpretation of all descriptive attributes.

binding.description: A coded concept defining if the medication is in active use.

element.short: Manufacturer of the item
element.definition: Describes the details of the manufacturer of the medication product.  This is not intended to represent the distributor of a medication product.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: RXD-20-Substance Manufacturer Name / RXG-21-Substance Manufacturer Name / RXA-17-Substance Manufacturer Name

element.short: powder | tablets | capsule +
element.definition: Describes the form of the item.  Powder; tablets; capsule.
element.comment: When Medication is referenced from MedicationRequest, this is the ordered form.  When Medication is referenced within MedicationDispense, this is the dispensed form.  When Medication is referenced within MedicationAdministration, this is administered form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded concept defining the form of a medication.

mapping.map: RXO-5-Requested Dosage Form / RXE-6-Give Dosage Form / RXD-6-Actual Dosage Form / RXG-8-Give Dosage Form / RXA-8-Administered Dosage Form

element.short: Amount of drug in package
element.definition: Specific amount of the drug in the packaged product.  For example, when specifying a product that has the same strength (For example, Insulin glargine 100 unit per mL solution for injection), this attribute provides additional clarification of the package amount (For example, 3 mL, 10mL, etc.).
element.comment: This is the quantity of medication in a package.  To specify the strength of the medication, the Ingredient.strength attribute is used.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional names for a medication
element.definition: Additional names for a medication, for example, the name(s) given to a medication in different countries.  For example, acetaminophen and paracetamol or salbutamol and albuterol.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Associated or related medication information
element.definition: Associated or related knowledge about a medication.

element.definition: Associated or related medications.  For example, if the medication is a branded product (e.g. Crestor), this is the Therapeutic Moeity (e.g. Rosuvastatin) or if this is a generic medication (e.g. Rosuvastatin), this would link to a branded product (e.g. Crestor).

element.short: Medication(s) or substance(s) contained in the medication
element.definition: The actual ingredient - either a substance (simple ingredient) or another medication.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: RXC-2-Component Code  if medication: RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXE-2-Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code / RXG-4-Give Code / RXA-5-Administered Code

element.short: Active ingredient indicator
element.definition: Indication of whether this ingredient affects the therapeutic action of the drug.
element.requirements: True indicates that the ingredient affects the therapeutic action of the drug (i.e. active). False indicates that the ingredient does not affect the therapeutic action of the drug (i.e. inactive).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Quantity of ingredient present
element.definition: Specifies how many (or how much) of the items there are in this Medication.  For example, 250 mg per tablet.  This is expressed as a ratio where the numerator is 250mg and the denominator is 1 tablet.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: RXC-3-Component Amount & RXC-4-Component Units  if medication: RXO-2-Requested Give Amount - Minimum & RXO-4-Requested Give Units / RXO-3-Requested Give Amount - Maximum & RXO-4-Requested Give Units / RXO-11-Requested Dispense Amount & RXO-12-Requested Dispense Units / RXE-3-Give Amount - Minimum & RXE-5-Give Units / RXE-4-Give Amount - Maximum & RXE-5-Give Units / RXE-10-Dispense Amount & RXE-10-Dispense Units

element.short: The drug concentration measured at certain discrete points in time
element.definition: The drug concentration measured at certain discrete points in time.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The median lethal dose of a drug
element.definition: The median lethal dose of a drug.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time required for concentration in the body to decrease by half
element.definition: The time required for any specified property (e.g., the concentration of a substance in the body) to decrease by half.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Definition of Medication Knowledge
element.definition: Information about a medication that is used to support knowledge.

element.short: Code that identifies this medication
element.definition: A code that specifies this medication, or a textual description if no code is available. Usage note: This could be a standard medication code such as a code from RxNorm, SNOMED CT, IDMP etc. It could also be a national or local formulary code, optionally with translations to other code systems.
element.comment: Depending on the context of use, the code that was actually selected by the user (prescriber, dispenser, etc.) will have the coding.userSelected set to true.  As described in the coding datatype: "A coding may be marked as a "userSelected" if a user selected the particular coded value in a user interface (e.g. the user selects an item in a pick-list). If a user selected coding exists, it is the preferred choice for performing translations etc. Other codes can only be literal translations to alternative code systems, or codes at a lower level of granularity (e.g. a generic code for a vendor-specific primary one).

binding.description: A coded concept that defines the type of a medication.

mapping.map: RXO-1.1-Requested Give Code.code / RXE-2.1-Give Code.code / RXD-2.1-Dispense/Give Code.code / RXG-4.1-Give Code.code /RXA-5.1-Administered Code.code / RXC-2.1 Component Code

element.short: active | inactive | entered-in-error
element.definition: A code to indicate if the medication is in active use.  The status refers to the validity about the information of the medication and not to its medicinal properties.
element.comment: This status is intended to identify if the medication in a local system is in active use within a drug database or inventory.  For example, a pharmacy system may create a new drug file record for a compounded product "ABC Hospital Special Cream" with an active status.  At some point in the future, it may be determined that the drug record was created with an error and the status is changed to "entered in error".   This status is not intended to specify if a medication is part of a particular formulary.  It is possible that the drug record may be referenced by multiple formularies or catalogues and each of those entries would have a separate status.
element.isModifierReason: This element changes the interpretation of all descriptive attributes.

binding.description: A coded concept defining if the medication is in active use.

element.short: Manufacturer of the item
element.definition: Describes the details of the manufacturer of the medication product.  This is not intended to represent the distributor of a medication product.

mapping.map: RXD-20-Substance Manufacturer Name / RXG-21-Substance Manufacturer Name / RXA-17-Substance Manufacturer Name

element.short: powder | tablets | capsule +
element.definition: Describes the form of the item.  Powder; tablets; capsule.
element.comment: When Medication is referenced from MedicationRequest, this is the ordered form.  When Medication is referenced within MedicationDispense, this is the dispensed form.  When Medication is referenced within MedicationAdministration, this is administered form.

binding.description: A coded concept defining the form of a medication.

mapping.map: RXO-5-Requested Dosage Form / RXE-6-Give Dosage Form / RXD-6-Actual Dosage Form / RXG-8-Give Dosage Form / RXA-8-Administered Dosage Form

element.short: Amount of drug in package
element.definition: Specific amount of the drug in the packaged product.  For example, when specifying a product that has the same strength (For example, Insulin glargine 100 unit per mL solution for injection), this attribute provides additional clarification of the package amount (For example, 3 mL, 10mL, etc.).
element.comment: This is the quantity of medication in a package.  To specify the strength of the medication, the Ingredient.strength attribute is used.

element.short: Additional names for a medication
element.definition: Additional names for a medication, for example, the name(s) given to a medication in different countries.  For example, acetaminophen and paracetamol or salbutamol and albuterol.

element.short: Associated or related medication information
element.definition: Associated or related knowledge about a medication.

element.short: Category of medicationKnowledge
element.definition: The category of the associated medication knowledge reference.

element.short: Associated documentation about the associated medication knowledge
element.definition: Associated documentation about the associated medication knowledge.

element.short: A medication resource that is associated with this medication
element.definition: Associated or related medications.  For example, if the medication is a branded product (e.g. Crestor), this is the Therapeutic Moeity (e.g. Rosuvastatin) or if this is a generic medication (e.g. Rosuvastatin), this would link to a branded product (e.g. Crestor).

element.short: Category of the medication or product
element.definition: Category of the medication or product (e.g. branded product, therapeutic moeity, generic product, innovator product, etc.).

element.short: Associated documentation about the medication
element.definition: Associated documentation about the medication.

element.short: The category of medication document
element.definition: The category of documentation about the medication. (e.g. professional monograph, patient education monograph).

element.short: Associated documentation about the medication
element.definition: Associated documentation about the medication.

element.short: Active or inactive ingredient
element.definition: Identifies a particular constituent of interest in the product.

element.short: Medication(s) or substance(s) contained in the medication
element.definition: The actual ingredient - either a substance (simple ingredient) or another medication.

mapping.map: RXC-2-Component Code  if medication: RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXE-2-Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code / RXG-4-Give Code / RXA-5-Administered Code

element.short: Active ingredient indicator
element.definition: Indication of whether this ingredient affects the therapeutic action of the drug.
element.requirements: True indicates that the ingredient affects the therapeutic action of the drug (i.e. active). False indicates that the ingredient does not affect the therapeutic action of the drug (i.e. inactive).

element.short: Quantity of ingredient present
element.definition: Specifies how many (or how much) of the items there are in this Medication.  For example, 250 mg per tablet.  This is expressed as a ratio where the numerator is 250mg and the denominator is 1 tablet.

mapping.map: RXC-3-Component Amount & RXC-4-Component Units  if medication: RXO-2-Requested Give Amount - Minimum & RXO-4-Requested Give Units / RXO-3-Requested Give Amount - Maximum & RXO-4-Requested Give Units / RXO-11-Requested Dispense Amount & RXO-12-Requested Dispense Units / RXE-3-Give Amount - Minimum & RXE-5-Give Units / RXE-4-Give Amount - Maximum & RXE-5-Give Units / RXE-10-Dispense Amount & RXE-10-Dispense Units

element.short: The instructions for preparing the medication
element.definition: The instructions for preparing the medication.

element.short: The intended or approved route of administration
element.definition: The intended or approved route of administration.

binding.description: A coded concept defining the intended route of administration.

element.short: The pricing of the medication
element.definition: The price of the medication.

element.short: The category of the cost information
element.definition: The category of the cost information.  For example, manufacturers' cost, patient cost, claim reimbursement cost, actual acquisition cost.

element.short: The source or owner for the price information
element.definition: The source or owner that assigns the price to the medication.

element.short: The price of the medication
element.definition: The price of the medication.

element.short: Program under which a medication is reviewed
element.definition: The program under which the medication is reviewed.

element.short: Type of program under which the medication is monitored
element.definition: Type of program under which the medication is monitored.

element.short: Name of the reviewing program
element.definition: Name of the reviewing program.

element.short: Guidelines for administration of the medication
element.definition: Guidelines for the administration of the medication.

element.short: Dosage for the medication for the specific guidelines
element.definition: Dosage for the medication for the specific guidelines.

element.short: Type of dosage
element.definition: The type of dosage (for example, prophylaxis, maintenance, therapeutic, etc.).

element.short: Dosage for the medication for the specific guidelines
element.definition: Dosage for the medication for the specific guidelines.

element.short: Indication for use that apply to the specific administration guidelines
element.definition: Indication for use that apply to the specific administration guidelines.

element.short: Characteristics of the patient that are relevant to the administration guidelines
element.definition: Characteristics of the patient that are relevant to the administration guidelines (for example, height, weight, gender, etc.).

element.short: Specific characteristic that is relevant to the administration guideline
element.definition: Specific characteristic that is relevant to the administration guideline (e.g. height, weight, gender).

element.short: The specific characteristic
element.definition: The specific characteristic (e.g. height, weight, gender, etc.).

element.short: Categorization of the medication within a formulary or classification system
element.definition: Categorization of the medication within a formulary or classification system.

element.short: The type of category for the medication (for example, therapeutic classification, therapeutic sub-classification)
element.definition: The type of category for the medication (for example, therapeutic classification, therapeutic sub-classification).

element.short: Specific category assigned to the medication
element.definition: Specific category assigned to the medication (e.g. anti-infective, anti-hypertensive, antibiotic, etc.).

element.short: Details about packaged medications
element.definition: Information that only applies to packages (not products).

element.short: A code that defines the specific type of packaging that the medication can be found in
element.definition: A code that defines the specific type of packaging that the medication can be found in (e.g. blister sleeve, tube, bottle).

binding.description: A coded concept defining the type of packaging of a medication.

element.short: The number of product units the package would contain if fully loaded
element.definition: The number of product units the package would contain if fully loaded.

element.short: Specifies descriptive properties of the medicine
element.definition: Specifies descriptive properties of the medicine, such as color, shape, imprints, etc.

element.short: Code specifying the type of characteristic of medication
element.definition: A code specifying which characteristic of the medicine is being described (for example, colour, shape, imprint).

binding.description: A coded concept defining the characteristic types of a medication.

element.short: Description of the characteristic
element.definition: Description of the characteristic.
element.comment: The description should be provided as a CodeableConcept, SimpleQuantity or an image.  The description can be a string only when these others are not available.

element.short: Potential clinical issue with or between medication(s)
element.definition: Potential clinical issue with or between medication(s) (for example, drug-drug interaction, drug-disease contraindication, drug-allergy interaction, etc.).

element.short: Regulatory information about a medication
element.definition: Regulatory information about a medication.

element.short: Specifies the authority of the regulation
element.definition: The authority that is specifying the regulations.

element.short: Specifies if changes are allowed when dispensing a medication from a regulatory perspective
element.definition: Specifies if changes are allowed when dispensing a medication from a regulatory perspective.

element.short: Specifies the type of substitution allowed
element.definition: Specifies the type of substitution allowed.

element.short: Specifies if regulation allows for changes in the medication when dispensing
element.definition: Specifies if regulation allows for changes in the medication when dispensing.

element.short: Specifies the schedule of a medication in jurisdiction
element.definition: Specifies the schedule of a medication in jurisdiction.

element.short: Specifies the specific drug schedule
element.definition: Specifies the specific drug schedule.

element.short: The maximum number of units of the medication that can be dispensed in a period
element.definition: The maximum number of units of the medication that can be dispensed in a period.

element.short: The maximum number of units of the medication that can be dispensed
element.definition: The maximum number of units of the medication that can be dispensed.

element.short: The period that applies to the maximum number of units
element.definition: The period that applies to the maximum number of units.

element.short: The time course of drug absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion of a medication from the body
element.definition: The time course of drug absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion of a medication from the body.

element.short: The drug concentration measured at certain discrete points in time
element.definition: The drug concentration measured at certain discrete points in time.

element.short: The median lethal dose of a drug
element.definition: The median lethal dose of a drug.

element.short: Time required for concentration in the body to decrease by half
element.definition: The time required for any specified property (e.g., the concentration of a substance in the body) to decrease by half.
